Football2009.ACCDiv:
The ACC has contracts with ABC for network TV, ESPN Networks for national cable and Raycom Sports for regional syndication.

It does not appear that there are any limits/minimums in terms of number of games over a season for the ACC with their national TV contracts. ABC/ESPN/ESPN2 televised a total of 31 regular season games each of the last two seasons, where 2005 had more games on ABC and 2006 had less. The ACC is guaranteed a game on Labor Day by ESPN and is set to appear as many as six times on Thursday nights on ESPN.
Football2009.BigTenDiv:
The Big Ten has a contract with ESPN for 41 games and a regional TV contract with the Big Ten Network (BTN), a FOX Sports Media Group & Big Ten joint venture. Under the contracts:

  • Up to 17 games on ABC
  • Up to 25 games on ESPN/ESPN2
  • Every team guaranteed two appearances on BTN, with one appearance being a conference game

For selection order, ABC has the first selection of games every week. Most weeks ESPN/ESPN2 will have the next set of game choices, followed by BTN. BTN will be able to leapfrog ESPN and/or ESPN2 on select weekends.
Football2009.BigEastDiv:
The Big East has contracts with ABC for network TV, ESPN Networks for national cable and ESPN Regional Television for regional syndication. This contract expires after the 2013 season.

At least three games are supposed to air on ABC, with a minimum of 17 games on ABC/ESPN/ESPN2. ESPNU has an additional minimum of five Big East games per season.
Football2009.Big12Div:
The Big 12 has a network TV contract with ABC. The conference also contracts with FSN for national cable telecasts and what would be considered regional telecasts. FSN also produces many PPV telecasts for the conference. Up to 18 games will air on ABC.

ESPN sublicenses a small number of games from FSN. When Texas vs. Texas A&M airs on ESPN on Thanksgiving, it counts towards ABC's contract.
Football2009.C-USADiv:
Conference USA has a pair of national cable contracts. ESPN owns the primary selections and CBS College Sports owns the all selections after ESPN. CBS College Sports also allows for local stations to purchase games to air.

ESPN owns the rights to approximately 10 regular season games and the conference championship game. CBS College Sports can select up to 24 games to televise and sublicenses some of their games to CSS for regional distribution.
Football2009.MACDiv:
The MAC has a national cable & regional syndication contract with ESPN Networks and a regional television package with SportsTime Ohio.

At least six regular season games will air on ESPN or ESPN2, plus a minimum of five games on ESPNU. For regional television, ESPN Regional TV will air games over six weekends on local stations and SportsTime Ohio will carry a minimum of three games.
Football2009.MWCDiv: The MWC has a national cable contract with CBS College Sports (formerly CSTV). CBS College Sports has partnered with Comcast to operate the MWC's regional TV network, the mtn. In turn, Comcast has the rights to select football games to air nationally on Versus.
Football2009.Pac-10Div:
The PAC-10 has a network TV contract with ABC. The conference also has a national cable contract with FSN. At this time, the conference does not have a regional syndication contract, allowing individual institutions to contract with regional networks.

ABC has the rights to 14 total games and FSN has the rights to 18 games. For 2009, FSN sublicensed games to Versus.
Football2009.SECDiv:
The SEC has a network TV contract with CBS and a national cable & regional syndication deal with ESPN Networks.

CBS has the rights to fourteen regular season games and the conference championship. Up to two of those games can be non-conference games. No SEC team may appear on CBS more than six times.

ESPN/ESPN2 has the rights to twenty regular season games and at least an additional thirteen games will air on ESPNU.

For regional syndication, ESPN Regional Television, under the name SEC Network, will televise a Game of the Week. ESPN has sublicensed a pair of regional cable syndication packages, one to FOX Sports South and one to CSS to manage and distribute.

Each school can air one game on PPV per season.
Football2009.SunBeltDiv:
The Sun Belt has a national cable contract with ESPN Networks. They also have a regional syndication contract with CST and CSS in a joint partnership called the Sun Belt Network.

At least two weeknight games per season will air on ESPN or ESPN2. Additional Sun Belt games can be chosen on a 12 day basis.
Football2009.WACDiv: The WAC has a national cable contract with ESPN Networks. At least ten games per season can air on ABC/ESPN/ESPN2 and ESPNU can select games. An additional regional syndication package of five games is managed by ESPN Regional TV and schools are free to sign deals with local or regional television stations.
Football2009.ArmyDiv: ESPN Networks is the rights holder for all Army home games and has elected to sublicense most of the games to CBS College Sports.
Football2009.NavyDiv: CBS College Sports (formerly CSTV) is the rights holder for all Navy home games and neutral site games designated as home games, except for the Army and Notre Dame games. The CBS College Sports contract expires after the 2018 season.
Football2009.NotreDameDiv: NBC is the rights holder for all Notre Dame home games. This agreement ends after the 2010 season.
